description.text:
Long extension for GoPro camera. Some design for manufacturing has been done. Design has been tweaked to print clean on my TOM. If these work for or don't quite fit please let me know so that I can see if the design could use an update.
RA = "right angle" version.

Print with support. Watch the layer count to make sure the gap thickness is about right. Some skeinforge settings will cause an extra layer to be added that will suddenly make the parts not fit.
Found a chisel worked great for removing the support. If they don't quite fit a small file works great to open up the slots to make the fit just right.

title: Rubber Holder Block for Lipo Fixation at Quadcopter

description.text:
Holding Block for a Rubber band to fix a Lipo Accu under a quadcopter frame. Blocks are fixed with M3 screws (just cut into printed hole with M3 thread drill).
I printed 4 of these and use 2 rubber bands (made of bicycle tube) to fix a 1000mAh Lipo to my Diatone 250 Quad, but all dimensions are parametric (OpenSCAD). Works great and fixes lipo very well.
Prints well in PLA w/o support.
Use OpenScad or Customizer to adapt it to required dimensions.

This lets you print a laptop stand with minimal material and print time. This stand will raise you laptop about 12 cm. The stand gives better viewing angle, and more room on your desk. Print as many copies of this model as you need. Connect the parts together with a couple of pencils, to keep all the parts on the same line. Just one of these stand parts is strong enough to hold my computer, which weighs about 2 kg. I printed them with 10% infill, it took about 40 mins per part.
Print with greater infill for a greater stability. This means you can print fewer parts.

Case of the original Odroid C1 (not the + )
Uses screws to keep itself shut instead of the silly clicking things from the original hardkernel design.
Did away with the breakout-part for the GPIO ports; and opterd for a more solid design.
Added a lot of ventilation as i noticed my odroid running 15+°C hotter than before when using the original case and did some remodeling on the 'struts' on the sides of the top.
I didn't foresee a hole for the IrDA receiver but that side is riddled with holes anyway so i'm guessing this could work. This case is very economical in plastic, thin walls supported by struts and lots of ventilation holes ;)

title: RSE-1 Bowden Extruder (cold-end)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hallo, noch nicht den passenden Bowden - Extruder gefunden?
Dann werft mal einen Blick auf diesen. Die Hauptmerkmale:
  • Einfach zu drucken
  • Einfach zu montieren
  • Einfach zu bedienen => https://youtu.be/fC4mwStBhmE
  • das Ding kommt mit genau einer (!) Sorte Schrauben aus
  • Modulares Design, Anpassungen sind super leicht vorzunehmen
  • grundsolide Konstruktion
    • Was ihr außer den gedruckten Teilen sonst noch braucht: 4 Zylinderkopfschrauben M3x30 (Ja, wirklich nur die...) 1 bis 2 Muttern M3 2 Unterlegscheiben M3 (ca. 8mm Durchmesser) 1 Feder (Bezugsquelle siehe .scad Datei, nicht lachen...) 1 "hobbed pulley" 13x8mm, 5mm Innendurchmesser 1 Kugellager Typ "608zz" 1 pushfit mit M5 Gewinde für den Anschluss eines Bowdens mit 4mm Außendurchmesser. 1 Nema 17 ;-) Für mehr Details bitte einfach einen Blick in die ausführlich kommentierte .scad Datei werfen. Translated by Google -> Hello there, not the appropriate Bowden - Extruder found?
    Then times throw a look at this. The main features:
  • Easy to Print
  • Easy to assemble
  • Easy to use
  • the thing comes with exactly one (!) Variety screws
  • Modular design, adjustments are super easy to make
  • rock solid construction
    • What do you except the printed parts else you need: 4 socket head cap screws M3x30 (Yes, really the only ...) 1 to 2 nuts M3 2 washers M3 (8mm diameter) 1 spring (source see .scad file, do not laugh ...) 1 "hobbed pulley" 13x8mm 5mm inside diameter 1 ball bearing type "608zz" 1 PushFit with M5 thread 1 Nema 17;-) Please just take a look at the detail commented .scad file for details. <- Translated by Google

title: UP!view - a RaspberryPi cam holder solution to observe remote LAN printing

description.text:
Update 2015/11/13: Added instructions for remote LAN printing. Be honest, how many houres have you spent in front of your printer observing the printing progres?
Ha ha, many like me. So this is the solution to leave the hobby room, garage or wherever your printer resides.
I added a raspberry pi with a pi cam to my UP!mini printer housing and i would share the parts with any other Up!mini user.
Don't worry, you dont have to modify your printer unrecoverable. No drills and cuts are needed. Thing you need to buy if you haven't already:
  • Up!mini Printer
  • Raspberry Pi and a power source
  • Raspberry Pi Cam
  • 30cm Pi Cam cable
  • LAN cable
  • optional Pi compatible USB WLAN dongle
  • 4 2,5x5mm self tapping screws to mount the Pi
    • Tools (in addition to your printer):
  • 2.5mm hex screw driver
  • Phillips screwdriver
  • soldering iron
  • possibly a hot glue gun
  • some software and instructions for the raspberry pi
    http://pimylifeup.com/raspberry-pi-security-camera/
    https://github.com/ccrisan/motionpie
    • Disclaimer:
    Be warned, all steps above are done at your own risk. I am not responsible or reliable for any damage or injury.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

loose

Notes: I assume you get the best results by printing all parts in the orientation shown in the picture. Printing of UPView_PiCase_TopClip.stl is a little bit tricky.
It needs to be very thin in the middle. I set my printer to 0.1mm layer height by using FixUp3d project
If you don't manage to print this part use some tape to fix the part on the top of the printer. You don't need to print the UPView_PiDummy.stl part. It is just a helper for the construction of the breakouts. Maybe you can use it for own applications.

• mounting the Pi Cam

  • change focus

  • Open and remove the top cover
  • Unscrew the four screws on the top
  • Now you can carefully move the top plastic part of the housing to the left.
    Be carefull not to tear of the power button cables.
  • Unplug the power button cord to completely remove the top housing part.
  • Unscrew the little spacer part on the right front side. Remove the Phillips screws and the hex screw. You need them to mount the Cam arm.
    • Installing the software on the raspberry pi:
  • I followed theese instructions http://pimylifeup.com/raspberry-pi-security-camera/
  • make sure to rotate the video image if you mount your cam in the same direction like I did. (cable leaves the box on top)
  • Open and remove the top cover - Unscrew the four screws on the top
  • Now you can carefully move the top plastic part of the housing to the left. Be carefull not to tear of the power button cables.
  • Unplug the power button cord to completely remove the top housing part.
  • Unscrew the little spacer part on the right front side. Remove the Phillips screws and the hex screw. You need them to mount the Cam arm.
    • replace this part with the cam holder. Mounting the CamHolder
  • First insert the ball into the CamHolder back
  • Use some glue or like i did, a spoon heated up with a lighter, to melt the ball inside the housing.
  • Place the cam on the four sticks. Be sure you are already using the 30cm flat cable.
  • Gently place the front cover on the four sticks.
  • Again, use some glue or the hot spoon trick to close the case.
  • Now place the ball to the CamHolder_Arm
  • If the clip does not grab the ball enought you can warm it and bend it a little bit together. I just used a drop hot glue after i set up the orientation to fix the angle.
    • Ball mounted to CamHolder back Cam placed on the four pins Closed case Fixing the focal length of the Pi cam Because we need the cam to see very close adjusting the focal length is required
  • with a sharp knife or a needle remove as much as possible from the locking glue.
  • screw out the lens. I used a small pliers and approx. a quart round. Others reported they used an eraser to rotate the lens.
    At this point a had a test setup with my already configured Pi (See instructions below) to adjust the length.
    • Mount the CamHolder unit to the printer
  • Now you can mount the CamHolder unit to the printer using the two screws you removed from the old white part.
  • Use the small clip to fix the cable on the top of the printer case
    • Mounting the PiCase
  • Clip on UPView_PiCase_TopClip on the top of your printer
  • Unscrew the upper screw on the right side of your printer
  • Hang the UPView_PiCase_Back (solid or lean) on the holder clip and fix it loose with the screw on the right side of your printer.
    • In red the holder clip Replace the top Cover
  • Bend the cable to let it exit to the right side.
  • Now you can replace the top cover to your printer.
  • Now it is a good moment to have a try with the PiCase_Cover
  • Snap the cover on the two clamps at the bottom of the back an carefully close it to the top.
  • Maybe some adjusting of the top clip and the PiCase_back is needed. I made an elongated hole for the screw to allow adjustment
    • The mounted PiCase back Mounting the Pi board to the back
  • Use four self tapping screws to mount the Pi board to the back
    • Connect the camera cable to the Pi
  • Self explaining. Keep an eye on the right orientation.
    • The connected cable Close the cover
  • Now, if not already done, remove all USB dongles, cables and the SD-Card from the Pi board.
  • Snap on the cover like in the test above and carefully close it.
  • Congratulations! You are done with the hardware
    • Closing the cover Reconnected USB WLAN/WIFI dongle Installing the software
  • Prepare your SD-Card as described in this instructions:
    http://pimylifeup.com/raspberry-pi-security-camera/
    https://github.com/ccrisan/motionpie
  • insert the card to your board and connect it to a power source.
    • And now feel free to post pictures of your make here Future vision
  • The UP!mini board could provide the needed 5V voltage for the Pi board to eliminate the additional power source for the Pi board.
  • Use some Pi io-Pins and some software to allow the Pi board to power up the printer and toggle the printer light.
  • Extend the FixUp3D software to provide an interface (a socket or http server) where the MotionPi software can fetch the progres and inject it to the OSD
    • Contributers welcome! Add remote LAN printing capabilityy to your UP!mini After some weeks of testing I can report that it is a possible and very stable solution to use the UP!mini via LAN.
    I installed the VirtualHere software on the Raspberry Pi. See details below. Connected the UP!mini USB cable to one of the Pis USB ports. After that I connected the VirtualHere windows client with the Pi, selected the UP mini USB port and started printing remote. Connect to your Pi (or other remote machine; linux and OSX will work also with the corresponding drivers) via SSH or a local terminal. cd /data wget https://www.virtualhere.com/sites/default/files/usbserver/vhusbdarm mount -o remount,rw / mv vhusbdarm /bin/ Create a startup file for to start virtualhere deamon on every boot. /etc/init.dS50vhusbdarm. vi /etc/init.d/S50vhusbdarm Paste the following content. In the vi editor press 'i', paste the content, press ESC, enter :wq and hit enter to save the file. #!/bin/sh umask 077 start() { echo -n "Starting vhusbdarm: " /bin/vhusbdarm -b echo "done" } stop() { echo -n "Stopping ivhusbdarm: " killall vhusbdarm echo "done" } restart() { stop start } case "$1" in start) start ;; stop) stop ;; restart|reload) restart ;; *) echo "Usage: $0 {start|stop|restart}" exit 1 esac Restart your device with reboot now Now Install and start the VirtualHere windows client and connect to your VirtualHere USB Hub and browse for your UP!mini to connect connect it by a double click.
    Now its time to start your first remote print job with the UP! Software.

title: Fishtank T5 Led night / mood light adapter

description.text:
Fishtank night/mood light I created this design to place a ledstrip into a spare standard T5 TL fixing, as our fishtank has two and one has become spare due to a high power led light.
We use it specifically for night lighting as the ledstrip is not powerfull enough to be visible when our daylight led lighting is on.
This fixing was designed for as 1047mm T5 light replacement, but could be used with other lengths as well, when the ledstrip and AL profile are modified. Update:
In included some images of the Led strip in action.
We set the strip to a blueish light as the moonlight also is a blueish light color.
However our the RGB controller does not seem to be able to provide an accurate led current overtime as the light be came to bright and we now have blue light.
Which also works very well in practice by the way, the nocturnal fish are very good to see.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

20-30%

Notes: I used 4 perimeters with a 0.4 mm nozzle, to enhance the objects strength

Instructions and parts For this the following parts are needed:
95 cm of sealed (RGB) Led strip (with power supply)
4 wires (for RGB) or 4 or 8 wire flat cable (I used 8 wire and connected these in pairs).
95 cm Aluminium profile, 15 x 15 mm.
2 pieces to the printed adapter
Some silicon paste / glue 1) I cut an approx 3 mm ident on both sides in the alu profile to make sure the ledstrip contacts can not touch the ALu profile.
2) The solder the wires onto own side of the led strip.
3) Stick the led strip onto the Alu profile
4) Do not forget to test the led strip.
5) Apply silicon past / glue onto one end of the profile and also on the inside of the printed adapter.
6) Slide the adapter over the ledstrip and profile and or cabling.
7) Repeat the last two steps for the other side as well. Next, mount it into a fixure like a normal TL light.

I wanted an easier way to move my drumkit around through my room. This is one idea i'm working on. Since i wanted to ask some people for feedback, i decided to share my current progress here. As a matter of fact, any feedback is welcome, so if you have any ideas, please chip in!! The obvious choice would be to go with "shopping cart wheels", but the problem is, they need to align first before the start rolling easily. So the first 10 cm is very tough, also they don't play nice with carpet. Using balls to roll around a wooden board has the advantage that it minimizes friction in any direction. The disadvantage is that the ball would move around under the board. (Still this works fairly well with a bunch of tennis balls, if you get the balls that pop out under it, and put them back on the other side of the board). This ring is to prevent that. Note that the little red rolls are not supposed to touch the ball at all times. The ball rolls around "freely" until it encounters one roll on the opposite side of the board's direction. The roll will go "between" the ball and the board, lifting the board slightly. This will (hopefully) allow the ball to roll freely from the board (but not freely from the roll). If you change direction, after a few cm another roll will take over. This is not my best scripting. I had to become a little pragmatic here and there to remain printability. The thin "walls" blocking the pivot openings are intended as supports for printing, and to be cut away after. It's designed to print upsided down. Also, i don't intend to 3d print the rolls or the ball. (-:

description.text:
This is an induction sensor mount specially designed for my Prusa i3 model (M505 5th generation from vendor Hesine 3D on aliexpress), but i guess it can be used on other models as well (Anet A8) . I was planning to use this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:671600 but it did not fit on my printer. The two screw holes are spaced for a 40mm fan.
On my model it fits nicely between the 40mm fan and the heatsink, so there is no need for longer screws.
The main hole is the perfect dimension to screw any LJ12A3-4-Z sensor inside. This is my first design, I hope it can be of use for anybody else :) I will post instructions to setup Automatic Bed Leveling on this specific printer once I have finished. EDIT: added a 17mm hole version, untested

comments.text: which electronics are you guys using for auto leveling? The included Melzi Board doesn't support that, right?
comments.author: martinschki

comments.text:
Hello,
As far as I know the Melzi board is compatible with ABL. Actually this is a software feature, not related to electronics. The sensor replaces the Z stop. With the sensor attached to the extruder (instead of fixed level on the static part of the printer), the software "knowns" the height of the extruder when the Z stop signal occurs on all 4 corners of the bed, thus can calculate the bed inclination on both X and Y axis.
comments.author: martinschki

description.text:
https://youtu.be/vtTou97ljL8 TWENTY SOMETHING SULLIVAN
Architectural Ornament 1881 – 1885
by Tom Burtonwood and Tim Samuelson
http://twentysomethingsullivan.com Louis H. Sullivan is often celebrated as a father of modern architecture. But if given the choice, it’s not what he would have wanted to be remembered for. His advocacy was for directing the human powers of thought, reason and creativity towards bringing buildings and their component parts to vital life. As in nature, all parts would relate to the whole. And each would reflect the interpretive powers of the individual, including emotion-stirring beauty uniquely of the work of the individual creator. By this process, a vital, perpetual modern architecture would be a natural result – not a hollow artificial goal. Often forgotten are Louis H. Sullivan’s earliest works where these powers are most visually evident. His earliest buildings created while he was in his twenties push upwards from the ground and blossom against the sky. The ornamental details pulse with living organic energy juxtaposed with the modular geometry that is the essence of architecture. Most of the buildings Sullivan created while in this twenties are lost, but many salvaged pieces of the ornamentation survive. Things that are alive need three dimensions to thrive.

description.text:
J'ai remarqué qu'avec le modèle initial j'avais toujours un peu de bruit, et l'impression que tout n'était pas très bien aligné.
J'ai donc adapté le design original pour transformer le roulement à bille, en roulement à portée sphérique pour le rendre auto-aligneur. j'en ai profité pour renforcer un peu et modifier la forme pour quelque chose d'un peu plus esthétique à mon gout.
J'avais également prévu une vis traversante pour immobiliser le système sur le châssis de l'imprimante, mais je ne m'en suis pas servi au final, ça tiens bien sans ça.

comments.text: This is a very clever design. I really like the self-aligning mechanism for the bearing. It too me a while to work out that you have to turn the bearing support sideways to get it to click into place and then rotate it back to horizontal before installing the bearing. At first I thought the support has printed too big, but I worked it out in the end. Thank you very much for sharing this brilliant design. Cheers!!

title: Fan for repairing a 40x10mm computer fan.

description.text:
I broke some blades on a 40x10mm computer fan so I decided to model a nice looking fan for it, just for fun. Turns out it works fine, so here it is. It fits fans with a ~22,5mm magnet ring.
The old fan is usually held onto the fan housing with a little plastic ring under the sticker. Separate the magnet ring, shaft and plastic from the original fan and install this one using general DIY skills, a vise and your thinking power. Trim as necessary if it rubs.

description.text: How better to "wind up" the helicopter series than with a Windup Helicopter! All components, including the spring, are printed in PLA. Video of prototype is here: https://youtu.be/fXo1cwoLAJE. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill).

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10% with exceptions

Notes: When printing "Chassis.stl", "Nose.stl", "Fuselage.stl" and "Tail.stl", supports may be required depending on your printer and printer settings. My prototypes printed fine without supports. Print "Key.stl", "Spring.stl" and "Axle Spring.stl" with 100% infill, remaining parts with 10% infill.

Study "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl".
Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl". Supports are optional, depending on your printer and settings, for printing "Chassis.stl", "Nose.stl", "Fuselage.stl" and "Tail.stl". My prototypes printed fine without supports.  Print "Key.stl", "Spring.stl" and "Axle Spring.stl" with 100% infill, remaining parts with 10% infill.
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.
Place wide rubber bands around the circumference of all wheels for traction.
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl". Start by assembling the entire chassis except for the rotors, their gears and the body parts ("Nose.stl", "Fuselage.stl" and "Tail.stl"). Next, attach "Fuselage.stl" onto "Chassis.stl", then add the rotors and their gears, and finally, attach "Nose.stl" and "Tail.stl" onto "Chassis.stl".
Apply light machine oil on the moving parts.
Once fully assembled, tested and aligned, a small dot of thick cyanoacrylate glue between the gears and axles will aid in holding the gears in position.
If you desire a more "grandkid / youngster" proof toy, I recommend printing the rotors and axles at 100% infill.
Feel free to comment if you have questions.
Hope you like it!

Printable Left and Right gantry for the Ord Bot.

A printable L/R gantry for the Ord Bot. It has been tested on a Hadron. This is made to couple with a square acme nut used with precision lead screws for the Z-axis (McMaster 95270A111) The gantries should be printed at 100% infill; they are still slightly flexible so a metal rod may be used to brace it (as pictured). This was derived from original Ord Bot specifications, all credit goes to Bart Dring: http://www.buildlog.net/wiki/doku.php?id=ord_bot:the_ord_bot

title: Replacement Ear Hook for Beyerdynamic TG H55c Headset

description.text:
The ear hooks of the Beyerdynamic TG H55c headsets tend to dissolve and break after a couple of years. I needed a quick replacement. So I made these.
At this time, the replacements cannot be twisted like the originals. I have attached the Rhino3D source file for those who want to improve the design.
Post-Printing instructions After printing you need to attach the hook(s) to the wire. I pushed the wire through the little hole in the hook and then extruded some filament into it.

A simple sword for a friend's costume. He is going as a pirate so we quickly drafted this sword and cut it into 4 pieces for printing. It is about ~24.9 inches long. It is sliced in 4 pieces total: cut once horizontally and once vertically (no supports needed this way). You will likely need to cut it yourself (netfabb) for your printer size. Came out looking quite nice and swings great! More pictures will come after Halloween.

The Inward Version

The laughing Buddha statue is probably the most known statue of Buddha. Chris Milnes creates "Pop-Buddha" project which is a line of 3D-printed sculptures of Buddha whose heads have been replaced with those of popular characters. I made some popular. You can also download cleaned without head statue of Buddha (!buddah_no_head.stl) and make your own Pop-Buddha.
Now are available the next Buddhas:
  • Yoda Buddha
  • Darth Vader Buddha
  • Trooper Buddha
  • Professor Farnsworth Buddha
  • Bender Buddha
  • Dr.Zoidberg Buddha
  • Batman Buddha

This is designed to all the use of a Sporty's A300 Hand held Radio with a wall power supply. It is used in place of the slide on battery pack in conjunction with a wall wort dc power supply. The base is attached to the radio in the same slide on method of attaching the radio to the standard battery.
The contacts of the base are simply screws that hold down the solder lugs for the power supply wires.

title: Mango tornillos hexagonales 4mm diametro - Handle for hex head 4mm screws

description.text:
Pequeño mango, diseñado para tornillos de métrica 4 con cabeza hexagonal (7mm).
Lo he diseñado para los tornillos del extrusor del carro X de mi Prusa i3, para un gregs-wade extruder, si no recuerdo mal, pero se puede utilizar donde se necesite.
Va un poco justo, se necesita calentar el tornillo para que entre bien. Small handle, designed for 4 metric screws with hexagonal head (7mm).
I've designed screw extruder my i3 Prusa x charriot, for gregs-wade extruder, if I remember correctly, but can be used where needed.
It is a fair bit, is needed to heat the screw between good.

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Nozzle 0.4mm

Infill:

Full (100%)

title: Foxy Cooling Duct: Directs air under a Mendel carriage.

description.text:
This item goes along with the Foxy Fan Duct and routes the air under the carriage to direct it at the head location. It mounds on top of the rear belt clamps for the X carriage. I marked this as a work in progress because:
  • It's a little too tight to the carriage.
  • I'm not sure if the flow is adequate.
  • The print was a little messy, and some design improvements could allow for a quicker print.
This print builds a lot of support material and the hardest part is getting the internal supports out. I had to jam some long nails and tweezers in there for a bit to clean out the duct.

Tamping stand \ station for 'standard' 58mm portafilter. Mine's from an Isomac Zaffiro but I assume others will work as well. When portafilter is on the stand it feels a bit more 'slippery' than I would have hoped but it works well enough for me.
There's more tamping stations on Thingiverse but the ones I could find didn't seem to have room for a double spout or were quite large so I made my own.
Designed with FreeCAD, source is attached in case you want to make changes (warning: the design is undocumented and somewhat messy). EDIT: added small chamfer to the bottom sticking-out edge, in my print this is a bit ragged probably due to the edge being too sharp.

title: Bigger Controller Knob for FUQI FQ777 Quadrocopter

description.text:
I really like the FQ777, but the short knobs of the controller gave me a hard time flying accurately. These longer controller knobs make it a pleasure to fly. Simply pull off the original short knobs and push these on. The long knobs can be stored in the spare-part compartment of the remote while carrying, so the controller will still fit in your pocket.
You can keep the original knobs there too, so you can switch between the two as desired.

Couldn't find any psion models anywhere, and wanted to make a costume for my son's Halloween.  Of course, he wants not just any psion, but a flayer.

title: Battery compartment cover for Sony TFM-110WB radio

description.text:
This is a direct replacement for the battery compartment cover for a 1965 Sony TFM-110WB AM/SW/FM portable radio.  Will also fit the AM/FM only variant.  
Careful attention was paid to matching the various curves and bevels.  Openscad source included for your modding enjoyment.

Print in black ABS.  I used neither built-in cooling nor support.  I just added a quick shot of cool air from a portable fan when it was printing the overhanging tabs.  
Add a 3/8" screw (same size as ordinary electrical switch plate screws), glue on two small pads of 1/8" open-cell foam on the inside of the cover and you're good to go.

This is a socket holder in chain form! Files provided for 1/4", 3/8" and 1/2" drive sockets. To make an open ended socket holder:
Print as many "links" as you have sockets - 1.
Print 1 "ring" and one "plug" To make a closed loop simply print a link for every socket. Print and add more links at any time. Links are designed to snap together. If you have some difficulty snapping them in, try angling so that one side of the bumped edge is inside the groove, then squeeze the other side in. Needle nosed pliers can also help to squeeze the outer prongs. Let me know how they work for you and post your makes! I haven't tried the 1/2" version yet.

comments.text: Printed @ 0.2mm layer thickness and "fine" quality.  My 3/8" sockets fit well and lock on tight enough.  I agree with the other comments that the ring-durability is suspect.  I'd also add that the ring-to-hub clearance seems a bit loose @ ~0.4mm. I'm slightly afraid the weight of the sockets will start pulling links apart.  Otherwise, it's a really nice design, and I love the concept.

title: QUBD TwoUp : x-gantry replacement ( trial narrow version )

description.text: This  is a trial design from my previous [v2] of right bracket, to provide extra 25mm x-axis print area. There is no change on the left half and lead screw nut holder.

• Can bring the nozzle farer than the stock printbed
    ( In other words, only those with a wider printbed can get the benefit. [v2] already can reach the at most right of the stock printbed)

  • Has shorter grip to the horizontal rods
    ( This requires precise output, which may be difficult for the original TwoUp without upgrades )

  • Requires smaller bearings ( $7.69/10pcs at Amazon)
    • Top : v2, bottom : v3 -- 25mm narrower

Tips The firm grip to the horizontal rods are the key for this design. I remember this level of precision was very difficult to achieve with the original TwoUp.
If your x-carriage suffers from sagging or wobbling, consider the following upgrades (or similar) to your TwoUp, in advance. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:962471 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:952796 ( You will need half of parts from this, anyway ) Instructions

  • Print the 2 pcs of the attached design ( one as it, one mirrored )

  • Print the rest of parts ( x_gantry_left*, and z_axis_holder ) from [v2] design.
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:952796/#files

Insert the M4 machine screw to the printed part. Then put the M4 washer, 2pcs of 624Z bearing, M4 washer. Inser the LM8LUU bearing. Optionally, you can put an LM8SUU bearing together for more stabilities. Hook the puley belt to the beraring. Then, sandwitch all 3 shafts. Hardware 7 pairs : M4x25 machine screw and nut
2 pcs : M4 washer
2 pcs : 624Z (ID4mm, OD13mm) bearing (e.g. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00AUB7M3C) 1 pcs : LM8LUU bearing ( from the original QUBD kit)
1 pcs : (Option) LM8SUU (for extra stabilities)

The small pink sticker in the cover photo represents the extended print width.
The printbed must be lifted a bit to prevent the hotend touch the printer base frame.

description.text:
This is a universal filament stand for standard spools (160 mm), but it also works with bigger spools up to 110 mm width. You just need two of the prints (they are symmetrical), 4 bearings type 6202RS (35 mm x 11mm with a 12 mm bore) and two aluminium rods with 12 mm diameter and 140 mm length. 
You can find the bearings easily on Ebay, Amazon etc. In order to assemble the rods and the bearings, put the rods into the freezer for about 1 hour. Then heat up the bearings for about 10 minutes in the oven at 100 °C (they're specified for 120 °C working temperature, so don't worry). 
The rods will be somewhat shrunk by the cold and the bores of the bearings will get a bit wider because from the heat and thus you can then simply plug them into each other. 
Once both are back to room temperature, they will be firmly connected. Then press the bearings into the printed parts and you're done.

title: Alhambra, Sharan, Galaxy Seat Handle (Rear or Middle Seat) VW SEAT FORD

description.text:
This is a Handle for my W-Reg (2000) 1.9 TDi PD 115BHp Seat Alhambra. I believe it's the same for the Ford Galaxy. I believe its the same for the Volkswagen (VW) Sharan (and maybe Touran). I had just one of the five left on the car when I bought it. That was already broken. So I got out BR's trademark "Cheapest Available" (tm) Pink filament, and printed a few of these babies out. Check it. It comes in two flavours. "Right" and "Left and Centre" - that relates to the seat position, not the side the handle is on (though I'd be real surprised if there was a handle in the centre of the seat back!). They have been built, and tested for the Right handle side. Fits with a little push. As ever, I recommend a Acetone Treatment for these and as it's got overhang I'm printing at 0.35mm Layer height (just going to check that's going to plan!) Enjoy, all you VWAG Diesel MPV Drivers just trying to keep the old girl running! License: Non-commercial, no derivatives, open source attribution. I can't enforce any of that, it's all BS. I just don't want to see someone using my files to add "Barry" or "Leeroy" to the handle and then re-uploading it "Look what I did!" - Brilliant. If you want to use this as a basis of your design - DO SO. Just no TRIVIAL derivatives. Change angles, Change faces, just none of this "My name on My handle" rubbish! Peace, out! EUR ING Andy Southern, aka BathRobotics. p.s. if you like this car part, why not download (or just view) the other designs I've done: 20/06/2016: VW Sharan / Alhmabra Rear Adjustment Handle http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1586975

This is a remix of the "Predator Mask with Battle Damage" by Geoffro.
I reduced the number of triangles in the 3d model for the bottom section, this resulted in the file size being cut by around half without any detrimental effect to the appearance of the model. I also added the Predator targeting lights, this is produced by using three 3mm superbright red LEDs powered by a CR2430 cell battery.
I printed mine using 20% infill and a 0.2 layer height, glue both sections together with hot-melt glue, then prime and paint (I finished with a metallic pewter spray paint).
The LEDs are fitted to the light assembly piece and the battery and switch are mounted on the back of the mask using the battery mount piece (this is shaped to fit on the mouth section of the mask), again using hot-melt glue to secure in place. I also fitted some wire-mesh to the eye cut-outs.

This is about 3.5" tall and uses two 5MM Green LED's. They are powered by a rechargeable 3.7 Volt LI-PO battery from an Estes Proto-x / Hubsan Q4 nano quadcopter. You just need to be careful that you don't let the battery drain completely as it is possible the battery will be damaged and unable to recharge. It uses the quadcopter USB charger to charge the battery.
You will just need to cut off the end of the charger and LI-PO battery and solder new connectors. I used Male & Female JST SM Connectors 2 Pin. There is an on-off switch for the lights and also a charging port on the bottom to charge the LI-PO battery. All the pieces are attached with super glue after printing. A piece of 1.75mm filament (green of course) was used for the handle

A humpback whale, capable of printing with no infill, and no support. (well, excluding that which is already included)
I highly suggest printing it with no support, pausing halfway through, and throwing a few small but powerful magnets inside, then stick to the ceiling, where a nail is. (You can find a nail using a powerful magnet) If the magnets inside are not enough to support its weight, add a few magnets on the outside.
If not, it also floats. Bath-toy?   (I don't know if small children can gnaw off pieces of plastic)
Maker Ed- this whale not only shows one how to print without support, vertically, but also about the Humpback whale. For example, one can clearly see barnacles on the the whale.

This is a completely new part made for hANDi Hand Orthose
The purpose is to make it easy to collect the lines from the fingers to the spring without having to make those tiny knots. I did Knut at first and that thing works just fine but you have to put tension on all 4 finger lines at once wile tighten it. On "Knut 2" you can tighten each line separately... and the spring is a separate screw to.. Of course "Knut 2" can be used for much more than on "hANDi"
There are 1 connection in one end and 4 connections in the other end.. the sky is the limit ;) There are two files.
One is made after correct measurements of the nuts.. That however were to tigt for me after printing so the other file is scaled up to 1.2 and that worked just fine...

author: joe1116

description.text:
A customizable artsy, geometricky box / cube. This started as a sketch on paper just drawing curves on the faces of a cube and seeing how they could combine together continously. I found three ways to do it, which split the cube into two identical halves and decided to model them in 3D. Curve type 1 has a quarter circle on each face.
Curve type 2 has a half circle on each face(well, 4 of the 6 faces anyways)
Curve type 3 has 3/4 circle on each face. All styles take two identical pieces to form a cube.
Hollow and solid versions are possible. Provided STLs are 50mm cubes with 5mm thick walls. Type 3 is the most interesting shape to me, but unfortunately the least practical to print since the walls are 0 thickness in places.
I have updated the scad and model for curve type 3, the faces now use partial ellipse curves to avoid the 0 thickness walls. The customizer and openscad seem to have problems previewing this curve type 3. It renders fine in OpenSCAD though. Comment and post your makes if you do any, thanks!

description.text:
Note this was made for the RAMPS 1.3 board. Slight improvements; leveled the board, added powerjacket and repositioned USB hole. Ventilation added, dimensions based on Sepa MFB25B12 12VDC fan http://nl.farnell.com/sepa/mfb25b12/fan-25mm-12vdc/dp/1217961. This case is used for a milling machine with relatively slow stepper speeds, no extruderheater and no heated build platform. The fan is connected to screw terminal D9, with the fan pin assigned to it. Given the fan is quite noisy, I think of adding a thermistor later on and tweak the code so that the Arduino takes care of adaptive cooling. Ventilation efficiency has not been verified with RAMPS driving a RepRap with extruderheater or heated build platform. 2011-08-24 Minor update (pcb space) of the covers 2011-08-25 The obvious showed after the first print: the fan had to be moved up (to get max airflow along the stepper drivers) 2011-08-29 Attached final OpenSCAD and .stl files.
2015-09-14 Added RAMPS 1.3 note
Same as the covers, the fan is mounted with self drilling screws or, better, hot-glue.

description.text: This is a 2d arc module for OpenSCAD that works for any angle between 0 and 360.. It takes arguments for the outside radius, thickness, and angle of the arc. It works by intersecting a ring with one or more triangles to create an arc. For every 90 degrees of arc, another triangle is added. Usage: arc(radius, thick, angle); radius: Outside radius of the arc thick: Thickness between the outside and inside radii angle: The angle of the arc, anywhere between 0 and 360. linear_extrude(height) can be used to make it 3d.

description.text:
A 608 bearing made from 6mm Airsoft BB's. Due to the limitations in tolerances, the inside diameter is not 8mm, the largest I could make work were M4 or 8-32 screws. M4 Bearing Dimensions 4mm x 22mm x 7mm
8-32 Bearing Dimensions 4.5mm x 22mm x 7mm Print at .1mm, airsoft bb's will fit, just push up on one side and angle the inner track up on one side while snapping in the last few bb's. Once you get about 4 bb's in, the bearing should stay together on it's own. Should fit a total of 7 6mm airsoft bb's. Breaking bearing in by rolling it on a surface with a bit of friction. It only took me a couple rotations before the bearing was spinning freely. Note - The M4 and 8-32 Outer tracks are identical. I just uploaded it under both in order to cut down on confusion.

description.text:
This Mason jar lid is part of a water purification system called electrocoagulation (EC).  Created by us folks at elequa, it's purpose is to hold electrodes suspended in a water sample to be treated with EC, a process which can do amazing things like clarify fracking water, kill bacteria and viruses, and even turn soda pop back into water!  
We are just finished with designing our prototype circuitry and software and are in the process of open sourcing it.  Follow along as we deliver this vital technology to the world through the power of open source!  Just visit www.elequa.io

description.text: This is a 250 class Tricopter. It uses a custom Multiwii board with an atmega328 as a processor. The arms can fold back for easy transportation, as well as crash protection. The arms will fold back instead of breaking. The yaw hinge uses four bearing to ensure smooth operation, and is very strong. There is a mount for a Mobius camera to be zip tied to the top for aerial photography; I have not tried FPV with it yet.The ESCs are Turnigy 12 amp, and get zip tied to the sides, where there are indents in the body plates. I used all M3 nylon screws to save weight, however metal screws were required for the arm hinges. It should still fly with all metal screws. This was designed so that the pieces that attach the body plates to the board and camera plates could be partially a soft material such as Ninjaflex for vibration dampening, but I have not found it to be necessary. I use plastic 5030 props, but 6in props should fit on the front. The rear arm will need to be s little longer for 6in props. The battery is either a Turnigy 1.8Ah or a Turnigy Nano-Tech 1.5Ah lipo. The 1.5Ah will last around 10 minutes, while the 1.8Ah will last around 15 minutes.

author: orthoid

description.text:
Pulled my design. I'm sad that I had to do this, but recently found out my design is being sold on Ebay for a pretty penny. I did not authorize this user to use these photos or anyone else's photos. A report has been filed, but its unknown to me if Ebay will pull the listing. 
I'm all for sharing and letting folks remix the design, but to go around blatantly using the exact photos on this site. . . and sell it without contacting me. . . lets just say disappointed. I was well on the way to a V2 of this design, something that would make it easier to build/assemble, I will post updates, but I will not be posting the files here. 
This is not a reflection of the community as a whole, I've met some wonderful honest folks, but it only takes a few rotten apples to ruin the bunch.
